newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian stocks drift ahead of elections.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian stocks drift ahead of elections.

text.p: Slovenian shares eased on Tuesday on low turnover as investors huddled on the sidelines, waiting for the November 10 general elections, traders said.
"There is not enough fresh money on the market and we could expect some fresh money just after elections," Davor Dubokovic, a trader at Eastbrokers said.
The SBI index fell 2.01 points or 0.17 percent to 1,188.10. Overall 14 shares were untraded, five fell and five rose.
Turnover fell to 92.6 million tolars from 107.7 million.
Traders said that turnover was expected to remain low until the elections on Sunday.
Bank SKB was the most actively traded and also the biggest gainer, firming 3.61 percent to 41,600 tolars on volume of 983 shares for total turnover of 40.2 million tolars.
Financial consultancy Dadas was the leading decliner, shedding 37.70 percent to 11,500 tolars on volume of 256 shares for total turnover of 2.8 million tolars.
Brokerage Dadas, owned by financial consultancy Dadas has been banned from trading on the Ljubljana bourse on Tuesday due to alleged illegal trading practices.
"I think today's ban of brokerage Dadas from trading did not influence the market significantly, because serious investors have been avoiding it for a long time anyway," Dubokovic added.
Since March, shares of financial consultancy Dadas, have plunged more than 95 percent.
